H0.text: Completing its life cycle is the process exemplified by the leaves of a tree changing color in the fall.

H1.text: Preparing for migration is an example of a tree whose leaves change color in the fall.

H2.text: Responding to its environment is what a tree does when its leaves change color in the fall.

H3.text: Beginning hibernation is a process observed in a tree whose leaves change color in the fall.

A5.text: Plants may respond both to directional and non-directional stimuli. A response to a directional stimulus, such as gravity or sun light, is called a tropism. A response to a nondirectional stimulus, such as temperature or humidity, is a nastic movement.

A6.text: It also regulates other responses including the germination of seeds, elongation of seedlings, the size, shape and number of leaves, the synthesis of chlorophyll, and the straightening of the epicotyl or hypocotyl hook of dicot seedlings.
